skill.name: ghe-changelog
skill.description: This skill should be used when updating the project CHANGELOG, tracking requirement changes, recording design decisions, or documenting version history. Uses git-diff to detect and categorize changes to both code and requirements. Trigger on "changelog", "version history", "what changed", or after significant commits.
skill.summary: Generate and maintain changelogs using git-diff to track code, requirements, and design changes
skill.author: Emasoft

security_audit.summary: All 95 static findings are false positives. The skill contains documentation and example bash scripts for changelog generation. External command patterns are hardcoded git operations with no user input. Filesystem access is limited to standard project directories and /dev/null redirections. No malicious patterns or intent detected.

content.value_statement: Projects need to track changes across code, requirements, and design decisions. This skill uses git-diff to automatically detect and categorize changes, generating structured changelog entries that follow standard formats.
actual_capabilities: Generate changelog entries from git commit history using conventional commit messages
Detect and categorize changes into Added, Changed, Fixed, Deprecated, Removed sections
Track requirements file changes with version comparison
Detect design and architecture documentation changes
Integrate with GHE workflow phases (DEV, TEST, REVIEW)
Prepare release changelogs with version bumping
limitations: Requires git repository with proper commit message conventions
Cannot automatically infer change categories without conventional commit patterns
Does not access external APIs or remote services
Best results when project uses structured commit message format

use_cases.title: Generate unreleased changelog entries
use_cases.description: After a sprint or development milestone, automatically generate changelog entries by analyzing git commits since the last release tag.

use_cases.title: Track requirements changes
use_cases.description: Monitor and document all changes to requirements files, including new requirements, version updates, and deprecated requirements.

use_cases.title: Document design decisions
use_cases.description: Detect changes to architecture documentation, design files, and ADRs to ensure design decisions remain documented.

prompt_templates.title: Generate changelog since last release
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a changelog for changes since the last release tag. Categorize commits into Added, Changed, Fixed, and Deprecated sections. Use conventional commit messages to determine categories.

prompt_templates.title: Track requirements updates
prompt_templates.prompt: Show all new and modified requirements since the last version. Include requirement IDs and version numbers.
prompt_templates.description: Show all new and modified requirements since the last version. Include requirement IDs and version numbers.

prompt_templates.title: Detect design documentation changes
prompt_templates.prompt: Check for changes to architecture, design, or ADR files since the last release. List files modified and summarize the design impact.

prompt_templates.title: Full changelog update workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the complete changelog update workflow: generate entries for all changes since the last tag, include requirements changes, detect design modifications, and update CHANGELOG.md with the new entries.

best_practices: Use conventional commit messages (feat:, fix:, change:, etc.) for automatic categorization
Version requirements files with semantic version increments when modifying
Review auto-generated changelog entries before release for accuracy
Link changelog entries to issues, PRs, and requirements for traceability
anti_patterns: Skipping changelog review before release - always verify auto-generated entries
Using vague commit messages that cannot be categorized automatically
Forgetting to version requirements files when making changes
Deleting or overwriting previous changelog entries

faq.question: What commit message format does this skill recognize?
faq.answer: The skill recognizes conventional commits: feat:, fix:, change:, update:, refactor:, and docs: prefixes to automatically categorize changes.

faq.question: Can it track changes in multiple git repositories?
faq.answer: The skill works within a single git repository. For multi-repo projects, run the skill in each repository separately.

faq.question: Does it require a specific CHANGELOG format?
faq.answer: The skill generates entries compatible with Keep a Changelog format. It inserts content after the header, so any standard markdown changelog structure works.

faq.question: How are requirements tracked?
faq.answer: The skill monitors the REQUIREMENTS/ directory for .md files. It detects new, modified, and deprecated requirements based on git diff and frontmatter fields.

faq.question: Can I customize the categories used?
faq.answer: The skill uses standard categories (Added, Changed, Fixed, Deprecated, Removed). Customization would require modifying the skill code directly.

faq.question: Does it work with annotated tags?
faq.answer: Yes, git describe --tags works with both annotated and lightweight tags. The skill uses --abbrev=0 to find the most recent tag.
